name: Nately
reviews_clean: very disappointed. we found stryve at the local walmart and liked it. we wanted a larger bag, so i ordered the original big bag on amazon.it arrived yesterday, we had some and liked it. then i checked the ingredients... brown sugar?! what the hell?by definition, biltong does not contain sugar or other sweetener for curing (i’ll turn a blind eye to raisin juice concentrate, even though that is also sugar, but not brown sugar).what makes this so frustrating for me is that the original stryve “biltong” from walmart does not contain any brown sugar (bought another bag today to confirm), so why the hell does the same item from the same company, albeit a larger bag, contain it?there is one reason manufacturers add sugar to meat products - sugar holds water increasing the total weight of the product, meaning they don’t have to use as much actual meat in the packaging. classic bait and switch.i love seeing biltong go mainstream, but only when it is actually biltong... and this isn’t it.

name: Kate Miller
reviews_clean: finding clean, minimally processed protein snacks for a busy life is more challenging than i thought! cheez-its and pretzels just don't satisfy my needs for an active, on the go lifestyle. but wait! here comes stryve biltong to save the day!biltong and traditional beef jerky are more different than you may assume. beef jerky is more tender due to the higher amount of fat (and in most commercial brands, carbs) with added flavorings and sodium. this biltong, however, has a much rougher texture that is quite chewy. the flavor is that of thick flank steak- flavorful, but not overly fatty or tender like a ney-york strip.the biltong in my bag was fresh, not moldy, and the bag was completely sealed. i could not be happier with this purchase, and the only problem is i've eaten the bag too fast. i will have to portion out the ounces separately next time- it's just so good and such an easy hit of 16 grams of protein throughout the day!

reviews_clean: i learned to love biltong while living in england. the product i got there was imported from south africa (of course). now that i'm back home in the usa, i was so glad to find stryve biltong! it's every bit as good as the south african original, and the price of the 'big bag' is exceptionally good, too. i'm a diabetic, and since biltong is almost pure protein, i can snack on it without having to worry about the carb content. thanks for a great product!

reviews_clean: as a south african i used to make my own biltong as it was pretty tough to find here in the usa. i was very excited when i came across stryve because the pricing wasn't much more than i could make it for and it was so much easier to buy and consume on a daily basis. initially they had some quality control issues but i have to say their overall product quality has improved tremendously... plus whenever i run into a bad batch (sliced too small, too dry, etc) i send them a photo of the product and they immediately respond and rectify the issue. customer service is among the best i have ever dealt with. everyone has a slightly different preference for biltong. some like it dry. some like it wet. i am fairly ambivalent but fair warning this will generally be on the slightly dryer side... which i find understandable considering the bulk nature of the manufacturing and the fact that they have to ship it with desiccant for quality control purposes.

reviews_clean: i'm surprised how low the reviews are for this product. i normally don't review things like this, but i hope people coming from the same place i am aren't too put off by them to give it a try. to be sure, i'm coming at this as a long time jerky and dried sausage lover that doesn't know what biltong is "supposed to be like." i also rather like the flavor of cloves, which don't dominate but come through strongly enough to be polarizing.what i don't like at all are the long term health risks of eating cured meats, and this seems like a great replacement. i picked up my first bag of this during a road trip because it was among the healthier options and split the better part of an entire bag with my driving companion over two days.no, they won't blow you away with how juicy they are relative to cured dry sausage. i'm sure there are traditional or locally made products that are better. the price is also a bit high relative to even healthier snacks like nuts and these bags might be too large if you're not sharing them among a couple people. they're calorie dense - that's the point - so you don't want to add these to an already complete diet if you're trying to lose or maintain weight.nonetheless, these have become a great go-to snack food and easy addition to lunches for me. i've bought several bags of both the piri-piri and green chile and am quite pleased. in terms of price per weight/calorie, these large bags are quite competitive based on the other offerings i've seen on amazon.it's a fair criticism to say that these don't quite match your taste or texture expectations - and i do look forward to tasting the competition - but i honestly find many of the aggressively critical reviews baffling.

reviews_clean: i'm always looking for ways to supplement my diet with more protein. i've been snacking on various kinds of jerky to curb hunger between meals. recently i discovered biltong. while the flavors are similar to jerky, biltong has a different texture. jerky is cut into rather large pieces and is often stringy, due to tendon and other connective tissue. biltong on the other hand is thinly sliced and, to me, easier and less work (therefore more enjoyable) to eat. i've only tried two brands of biltong, stryve and kalahari. flavor is comparable. but stryve is a bit thicker than kalahari. and based on my initial comments comparing jerky, kalahari is my preferred brand of biltong. stryve is less expensive and is worth a try and still 100% recommended, i just prefer the other brand.

reviews_clean: whatever i hoped these snacks to be is irrelevant because this product is inedible.firstly, 0 carbs promised is not the 1 to 2 carbs these contain because of raisin juice and brown sugar. sugars are more than the granular white stuff used for baking and coffee with cream. all sugars metabolize down to glucose which is the form in which they are used by our bodies. duh.secondly, the taste of every flavor in the variety pack i received is, well, disgusting. even one of my friends who will eat nearly everything took a piece, chewed a couple of moments and spit that stuff right out of his mouth. this process was repeated by a few more people. we are a small galaxy of friends, but i can confidently say that the bite/chew/spew was pretty much our universal response.the biltongs look great, are in really nice thin pieces, smell great and are properly dried, but it is all a lie. ugh. i suppose if someone likes horrible tasting snacks, this might be perfect for them, but i doubt it.plus, this deserves no stars or minus-stars, but you have to give at least one star in order to review. this really deserves no stars.and, one more thing: this seems to be a real and responsible company. they have a nice web site and seem like real nice people. maybe there is something amiss in the production of the meat. perhaps the spices got all wonkified. some kind of production misstep. i wanted so much to love these.

name: NJD & DMD
reviews_clean: biltong is a form of dried, cured meat that originated in southern african countries (south africa, zimbabwe, namibia, botswana and zambia). various types of meat are used to produce it, ranging from beef and game meats to fillets of meat cut into strips following the grain of the muscle, or flat pieces sliced across the grain. it is related to beef jerky in that they are both spiced, dried meats; however, the typical ingredients, taste and production processes may differ.i recently started a high protein low carb diet and needed something to snack on that's also healthy. i love beef jerky and was also curious to try biltong, so i ordered this. i love that this is a family founded/run company. as the product description explains, this company started with the owner's grandpa who was a south african butcher known for making incredible, delicious biltong. his grandson now, via brooklyn biltong is introducing this beefy, delicious treat to america, using the family recipe and methods. unlike most processed jerky, it's made with grass-fed beef, and it's always sugar free, nitrate free, and gluten free. it's really nutritious with 15g of protein per serving, 2g of fat, and 0g carbs (my favorite part). there's also no added sugar. the flavor is wonderful. i can't handle anything spicy and this has a tiny trace of spice to it but definitely tolerable. this biltong is marinated in vinegar and spices before being air dried, a process that gives it an incredible steaky flavor, and tender, chewy bite. i think the amount of chew in each piece is perfect. not too soft, and not like leather that makes your teeth hurt.like the description provides, it's a great idea to use this in other things too. you can top pizza or a salad with it. i took the suggestion to chop it up finely and include with my morning eggs. it was really good. the possibilities are endless really. but i honestly love this as a snack. i love that it's keto compliant!overall, i highly recommend this. it's a bit pricey but all jerky is and this is clearly better quality. i like this and will be ordering more. i think you'll like it, too. enjoy!

reviews_clean: i've eaten jerky for decades now, from small mom/pop setups in tx, to larger name brands (yuck). luckily the internet (and rating systems) have allowed me to avoid the bad jerkys. everyone has differing tastes, so my review is partial to what i like, which is:1) dry, but not impossible to chew. the meat comes apart enough where a bit of saliva and chewing make it easy to eat. some dry/dense jerky's require many minutes of hydration and chew to consume.2) does not seem to have any gristle/fat chunks that some other brands i've tried have.3) does not use soy sauce (therefore gluten free).4) minimal processing and not too many ingredients (kiss principle).5) no overpowering sauces/spices so the meat/smoke flavor actually comes forth well.6) not too smoky, nor sweet, not too spicy either.i bought 3 pounds for my employees and it was gone in almost a week. i like this one the best (flavorwise). i do wish it was a bit spicier, but i do like things pretty spicy (which could obscure/hide the meat flavor)

reviews_clean: so, let me start by saying i'm a bit of jerky connoisseur. maybe even a little bit of a jerky snob lol. as such, i don't care for things like jack links. although they have awesome commercials, it is, in my opinion, not "real" beef jerky. now, i don't know how the rest of the world defines "real" beef jerky, but this is the easiest way i differentiate the real from the not so real- if your jerky says "refrigerate after opening" or "use within 7 days of opening," i'm sorry but that's not real jerky. the whole point of jerky, in my mind anyway, is that it takes a long time to go bad- it is real, dried, meat.now that i have that out of the way, let me say that if you like "real" beef jerky, this stuff is awesome. if you prefer the more moist "jerkies" like jack links, ball park, etc., you will probably still like it. it is lean, so not real greasy, and the flavor is awesome. it is a little moist (not dry and super flat like love's brand jerky- which is still one of my favorites), but not too moist. i've had most of their flavors, and though i don't care for the "original", the "old fashioned" and "carne seca" lines are amazing. the "tasting kitchen" flavors, while not my favorite, are interesting as well.now, to address the whole "refrigerate after opening" thing, people's choice actually says on their website that they recommend against refrigerating their product, which is really refreshing. it does have an expiration date of one year after packaging, but i promise it won't last that long :).also, if you are one of those people (like i once was) that believes that jerky should come from a beef state like texas or oklahoma, do not fear. this stuff comes from downtown los angeles, but it is freaking amazing.i will probably never be able to label a beef jerky my favorite, but this one is definitely in my current top three (love's(robertson's), buc-ee's peppered, & people's choice).so, to sum all of my rambling up, you should try this jerky. if you're not sure, try a smaller bag- i promise that the next time you'll be buying more. and, i did not receive any sort of discount or freebee from people's choice for this review. although, people's choice, if you're listening, i wouldn't turn down a discount! lol

name: Major Wager
reviews_clean: this jerky is reminiscent of the sort i used to carry years ago on long hikes. i experienced no carb highs and crashes, just sustained energy accompanied by a longer period of feeling full. i've now removed all sugar and grain from my diet for required and personal reasons. that's been a good move for me, but it's not a lifestyle change that offers a breadth of relatively appealing snack options that don't require 45 minutes to prepare. this version of people's choice beef jerky i can snack on straight out of the bag. i think it's grand, and clearly many others who've written reviews here do, too. but there are also several categories of negatives i'd like to address, because some of the negatives are actually positives, some can be avoided by reading the product description, some can be explained through general knowledge of what ingredients are.* "it's dry." i've always thought beef jerky was supposed to be mostly dry, but not completely dry. it's nice to have just enough moisture to keep chewing on a piece (as you would gum) to reap the flavor rewards. that's one of jerky's neat benefits. but if you're upset it's "dry," check out the product description. i see no misrepresentation of general moisture content there.* "it's not tough enough" or "it pulls apart too easily." the jerky in my bag wasn't easy to pull or even bend apart against the grain. with the grain, pulling was easier, but i'd expect that. my teeth played tug often enough, and i must have terribly weak hands, because i couldn't make one full strip of jerky rip with and against the grain into a stack of pieces. i could, however, cut it into a stack of pieces with a knife. if really, really tough, hard-to-separate jerky is what you're looking for, then this version might not be for you.* "it's too greasy" or "it's fatty." i wasn't constantly wiping my fingers on a towel to remove a greasy coating. in fact, i didn't have to do that once. i found it pretty difficult to visually distinguish much fat in the product. that said, fat is what helps impart flavor to meat, and all fats tend to feel greasy. nicely marbled beef is far preferable to cuts with little fat. you'd hope there was something of fat left in a dried meat product if you want some flavor. the product label pictured above says there are 2.5 grams total fat in each serving. a serving of classic lay's potato chips contains 10 grams total fat. "greasy" is a subjective sensation, but still, it's no trouble to check how much objective fat is in a product.* "there's no pepper in this 'peppered' jerky." well, there's no ground black peppercorn in this peppered version. however, there is paprika, and a nice dose of it. paprika is a fine powder made from plants in the pepper family. think bell pepper, red pepper. different paprikas produce different tastes. this jerky has a spicy quality. in the plant world, there are peppers, and there are peppers, and then there are more peppers. the ingredients list usually tells you which basic sort of pepper you'll find in the product.my personal "complaints"? this product is worth all the pennies. my pocket book just wishes it cost fewer pennies, because i plan to keep ordering. oh, and there was some spice residue left on my plate after munching. why couldn't all that tastiness stay on the strip? ;)

reviews_clean: first, i must say that jack link's is my go-to jerky brand. i sometimes branch out and dabble in some fancy brands with fancy flavors, but i never stop buying jack link's. i'm unable to replace the value of the flavor, texture, and price point with any other brand.now, to zero sugar. for me, fails on all three counts.flavor – seemingly way too salty to compensate for lack of sugar. even if it doesn't have that much more salt, it tastes like it does. the peppery taste that others complain about – well, i like pepper. jack link's peppered is one of my two must-haves (the other being sweet n' hot). this, however, is a weird pepperiness that doesn't excite me. it's not so much a flavor you taste while actively first sinking your teeth into it, but rather a weird bite that comes out as you relentlessly try to gnaw it... which leads me to...texture – only flavor of this brand that is dry, stringy, and super-tough. some pieces have been so tough, i had to throw them away. i literally couldn't even get the chewing started. sugar must be a required ingredient to maintain chewability, tenderness, and anti-stringy texture. last point...price – not only is the value not there for reasons mentioned above (inedibility, to sum up), but because it was more expensive per ounce, it's more loss than just, "i don't care for this flavor"... it's, "i paid what for that?"perhaps this has fans out there... fans with very strong teeth who do not require the same level of moisture in foods as i do.... and like lots of salt and weird peppery zing (or are so dedicated to no sugar they are willing to tolerate it).i am not one of those people.bring on the sugar...

name: DDerr
reviews_clean: this product is so unbelievably salty that it's practically inedible. now, i am fully aware of the fact that most other beef jerky and beef stick type products are quite salty, but this is far beyond the usual salt/sodium level of any such products i've tried.this isn't merely a subjective taste perception on my part, but let me back it up with objective facts, which should be alarming to any health-conscious individual: an 1-oz serving of this product contains 640 mg of sodium, which is a whopping 27% of the dv (daily value). in other words, a mere 1 oz of this product, which is literally only a few bites, contains nearly 1/3 of the sodium that the fda recommends that an average adult consumes the entire day. in comparison with a similar product of the same size, the original beef stick by lorissa's kitchen, an 1-oz serving contains 330 mg of sodium, which is 14% of the daily value. mind you, the latter product is already quite salty, on the higher end of most people's sodium threshold, and yet the sodium content in this jack link's product is just shy of double that of the lorissa's kitchen product. incredible, and incredibly disappointing.this is very unfortunate because i had a positive impression of jack link's before trying this product, and i had high hopes for it. i had even added it to my "subscribe & save" orders here on amazon... but i promptly cancelled this subscription after i tasted it and found out how ridiculously and dangerously salty it was.by the way, i've worked for the better part of 20 years as a r&d food scientist, and i am also a former registered dietitian, so i definitely know what i am talking about when it comes to taste, flavor, health, nutrient levels, etc.
